chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Hey guys, Avi here, and welcome back to our Python programming series.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Today, we're going to dive into the fundamentals of Python, which is variables.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Understanding variables is vital to programming because they help store and manage data within our programs.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: So what exactly is a variable?

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: You can think of it as a storage box where you can keep different kinds of data.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Imagine you have a friend who's turning 20 years old.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: You can store that number 20 in a variable.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Or let's say you want to store a piece of text like, my name is Avi.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: You can put that sentence or string in a variable.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: The process of creating a variable in Python is straightforward.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: You start by choosing a name for your variable.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Let's go back to our friend who's turning 20.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: We'll create a variable named age.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Then you can use an equal sign to assign a value to your variable.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: So age equals 20.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Now age holds the value 20.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: When you want to use that value later on in your code, all you need to do is refer to age.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: But what about our sentence? My name is Avi.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: In Python, we can store text data or strings in a variable.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: For example, we can create a variable called sentence and assign it our text.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Sentence equals my name is Avi.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: That string, my name is Avi, is denoted by quotation marks.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: And now the variable sentence holds that string.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Variables are incredibly useful.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: They allow us to manipulate data in many ways, but that's something we'll explore further in future discussions.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: For now, I just want you to understand how to create these variables.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: One of Python's nifty features is multiple assignment.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: This allows us to assign values to multiple variables at once.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Let's say we have several friends celebrating birthdays.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Sarah is turning 16, Bob is turning 21, Mike is turning 17.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Instead of creating a new variable for each friend, we can use multiple assignment like so.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Sarah, Bob, Mike is equal to and then each of their respective ages, 16, 21, 17.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Now Sarah holds the value 16, Bob holds 21, and Mike holds 17.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Another scenario where multiple assignment is handy is when you want to assign the same value to multiple variables.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Say Sarah, Bob, and Mike are all turning 17.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: You can assign the shared value by using Sarah equals Bob equals Mike equals 17.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Now all three variables hold the value 17.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: You might be thinking that's nice, but how is this useful in real life?

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Well, imagine you're a teacher with a list of students scores from a recent test.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: You could use variables to store each student's score and then calculate class statistics.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Or perhaps you're building a social media app where each user has a profile.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: You could use variables to store a user's details like their name, age, and location.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Knowing how to use variables gives you the power to build complex and interesting applications.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Now let's see if you can apply what we've just learned.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Try to create two variables in one line, one for your name and another for your age.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Remember, your name should be a string that is in quotation marks, so don't forget to add quotes.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Hopefully you managed to do it.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: If not, no worries. We're just getting started.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Here's what your code might look like.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Name comma age is equal to Avi comma 22.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: To check the value stored in name and age, you can simply refer to the variables.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: Today, we've covered some fundamental concepts, understanding what variables are,

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: how to create and assign them, and how to assign multiple variables at once.

chunks.title: Lect
chunks.text: That's it for this video, guys. Thanks so much for listening, and I'll see you in the next video.
